Hard hit.

...hard hit. Heineken much more in line over the Heineken brands, much more inline with our overall portfolio around the 3% was an improvement versus the end of the year, but that's too early to cry victory and that's certainly not what we want to do.
At the same time, you see Dos Equis growing at 15% year-on-year, growing very fast. The Tecate brands, which is much more a mainstream position in its pricing on the West Coast is a bit down as well.

I add one dimension on the light to bring in perspective. We ask basically for the same price for the light beer as for the regular beer. There's a 1.5% difference of alcohol degree, you've got less for the bucks. And in times where people are really looking into down trading, treating themselves, well, lesser than before, that's definitely plays a role.

A lot of people have asked me, yeah, but why don't you decrease the price to boost your volumes? Now that's exactly what we want to avoid. Heineken Light was to address different drinking occasion, it's a premium product. So we prefer accepting that higher decrease in our sales than going for margin diminution just because we have to address temporary crisis. So that is where we stand. But it's very logical in the actual context that you see the light version declining more, it's quite logical.
Thank you.
Are there calls from the web?
Right. We take one, and we take one and then (01:31:14) -
Thank you. We have two questions from the audio line. Our first question comes from Gerard Rijk from ING. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. I've two questions. First about Eastern Europe and the profitability and the market share gains that you have booked in several countries. Do you think that we are at the start of that momentum of gaining market share or what's your market share or were your market share gains mainly based on more faithful pricing based on more faithful input cost in 2011 versus your competitors?

Second question is on Russia, I just understood that Russia is rebuilding profits at the end of the year or in the fourth quarter. Can you elaborate on that why that is happening? And has there been, is that due to the loading effects, pre-excise?
And the third question is on Nigeria, 10% up organically in volumes in 2011. In January something happened in that country. What has been the impact of the January events?

All right. Let me start in the reverse order by Nigeria. If something would have happened, we would have informed you. So we never give trading updates outside of the quarters. But take it from us that if something really nasty would have happened, we would have informed you. This is not a case.

Your second question is about Russia. Now I was in Russia just the last week. I think what we have been, it's a very phased exercise where you have to go back in time, when we have that enormous excise duty increase, we pushed our price increases too early and too high.

We lost tremendous market share. The volume base at which we were then operating was totally unsustainable going forward. It was a year where we made very decent profits. But once more, this is a heavy operation in Russia, with a very large industrial and distribution base. And going forward that diminished volume share was just not acceptable going forward.

So what we have been doing, it is to, of course going to a long movement of dealing back the price increases to the market. So you regain your share, but at the same time you lose disproportionally your profitability because you take a kind of a double hit in this kind of thing. Now we have been regaining share in an incredible way, we grew our business volume wise 24% last year on a market which was down around 2%.

So that is in itself a sterling performance. But it is out of the past we took the lesson to be a price follower. We are not a market leader, we have to be very clever here and not apply the traditional kind of broad leadership approach that we take. We have to observe and take the niches into market. We operate in a lot of regions in Russia and a lot of times also these price increases they go region-by-region even brand-by-brand and SKU-by-SKU.

So, what the Russian organization has been doing is to really boost its capacity of understanding how you can take price in the market, in a competitive dynamic. And also the second half of last year, they started again to price up slowly and slowly and slowly.

And this is bringing us, again, territories where we have more and more acceptable margins going forward. Now again now in January, you have again an exercise duty increase and we take a very cautious view. We might have again a little dip, but we will take it up.

Russia is a very difficult market, make no mistake. There is high pressure from the authorities on it to operate. It is a difficult market. I'm not so sure about the growth potential of next year that it might be minute or less likely decreasing, but what we concentrate on in Russia is on the one hand we are in, I would say, value plus proposals. We concentrate on much less brands than we did before, but we do it more thoughtfully and reaping economies of scale doing that. And on the other hand, we keep on investing in the top end portfolio. You have a very laddered market with a lot of price points in direction market. That makes it still a very attractive market and so we invest disproportionately in the higher end of the markets. And our key brands, Heineken and Amstel have been increasing in Russia, a big thanks, we're very satisfied the way we go. And that also increases your mix, if you want. That is the policy that we follow in Russia going forward. Hope that gives some clarity.

And finally, if the gains of share and CE are price driven, I would tend to say no, though, I cannot exclude that marginally it can happen, if we gain some share in Poland. In the context of the competition that we face in Poland, yes, it is at this, but we are not the aggressors in that context. But I would say that in the countries where we perform well, I would not make the statement that we gain our share on the back of diminishing prices in our portfolio.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Thomas Russo from Gardner Russo & Gardner. Please go ahead.

Hi, you've left very little uncovered with a thorough explanation, great results. But Jean-François, I wondered if you could take the Vietnam example, and look out say the next three or five years. You've grown the capacity at Danang and Ho Chi Minh, but I understand that it's now your second largest worldwide market for Heineken brand. And something that grows well from this level is going to require I suspect more capacity. Tell us how you look at Vietnam, say, going out for the next three to five years, scale it up?

In Vietnam, we have master plans in place to continue to expand capacity on existing locations. So, we didn't announce any Greenfield. We have space enough to increase capacity as demand goes. And those plans are in place in Vietnam, Tom, to follow the growth that we continue, whether we expect to continue structurally.
Can the growth accelerate from here now that it passed into that number two status for Heineken worldwide, how fast is the brand growing?
Over 20% last year.

And, René, for you. I look at the very low borrowing costs and I see that Heineken has close to €5 billion of fixed liabilities coming due over the next four years. You'll probably want to stick to the healthy dose of leverage for the future. What can you do to extend the terms even before the 2013 and 2014 maturities come due to prepare yourself for an environment where doing so later might be very disadvantageous in terms of the then existing market rates of interest?

Yeah, you have seen it right, we have close to €2 billion to refinance in 2013. And conservative as we are, we will go to the markets obviously, largely before that to cover the needs. And if you look how bond markets are at the moment that looks a pretty good time.

Well, very good. And then, René, do you take any lessons from your balance sheet liability management and then look across to the pension liabilities in this extraordinary low rate environment, what steps does it drive you to towards the pension and health liabilities?

And so in the pension, in fact, we have two big pension funds, one in the U.K., one in the Netherlands. They are a bit differenced liabilities in the Netherlands are limited, because we are only obliged to a maximum premium to be paid. So officially the liability is limited. That is different for the U.K., where part of the pensioners have to write to an obligatory indexation. What we have done in the U.K., we have closed the pension fund for the new people sort of people who are entering the company come in on a different scheme and in that way we try to manage the deficits, which is clearly there in the U.K. fund.
We refunded that.
And we have obviously with the trustees a program to refund what we will contribute increases with the profitability of the company, but we make major efforts to close the gap.
Thank you.

Yeah, Ian Shackleton from Nomura. Two questions on the marketing spend. I remember when you did the Paris presentation in the 2010, I seem to takeaway feeling that this was a multiyear focus in increasing marketing. And we seem to get a slightly different message today that we've closed the gap. Are you happy that we're marketing the net sales somewhere in the 12% to 13% range? You really have closed that gap with big FMCG or is there still a further leg to come in at some stage?

And the other question really looking at slide 23 that René showed us. It looks quite dramatic to have gone through 11.3% to 12.8% of revenues. But it does strike you had some quite big changes in scope in that period that probably helped with the sale of the wave, they don't see FEMSA coming with probably higher number. I mean what was the true organic number of those two years in terms of marketing increase?

So, well, what we set organically we increased marketing by about 4%, but what is much more important and because this €2.2 billion is quite a big back of activities, things which are seen by consumers, not seen by consumers and one of things Alexis is doing is making sure that we get much more money out of the marketing we spend.

And he is rationalizing on things like market research, not in the sense that you don't do market research, but much more combining, that's getting learnings out of more markets, getting contracts over markets. So, the increase which the consumer-facing spend has is much higher, is more than double of the 4% increase you have seen, that is around 9%, 10% is the real increase which touches the consumer.

And if you like to go back to, René showed a table where you saw that our marketing and sales expenditures they dropped quite a bit with the financial crisis to 2008 or 2009. It came back to levels which we historically had before with 2007 being a very high year, because of the introduction of Heineken Light 2006, 2007 were those years.

So, one has to realize that at the level that we have reached now, we feel pretty comfortable that we can carry out the programs, it's multi year programs. Building brands is nothing you're doing one year and then you stop. This is a way of life. It's really what René has pointed about is the consumer facing. That is what is the most important in putting our money in priority there.

So, building the pull rather than the push. Of course you have to do both, but we were perhaps in the past a little bit more skewed to the push and not enough to the pull. And so, under the guidance of Alexis Nasard, we are really rebuilding our capabilities in creating the pull. This is all at the core of being brand led and consumer centric, it's about that. And hence it's not only about the level of money you spent, it's about what you do with the money.
So, just to be clear, medium-term we should expect marketing over net sales to stay somewhere around with the 13% type level, but within that the quality is probably improving over time?

Yeah, that is what you can take and you should certainly not draw the conclusion that you say you come back on things you have said in the past. The company we are growing, where we had three years of an exclusive focus on cost and cash, because it was so urgent in the company. We turned the ship towards top line growth, winning in the marketplace, winning volume and value share, investing behind our brands and that's what we are doing and you see a lot about what has happened.
Thank you.

Chris Pitcher from Redburn. Following on from that point, you mentioned consumer facing spend was up 9% and total sales and marketing was up 4%. Is it broadly a 50-50 split at the current level? Because I'd imagine the businesses that you acquired are probably more skewed towards the push than the pull side. Is that broadly the split to spend?

No, no, no, no, I mean I won't enter even in the beginning of response on that. Look, your question is very valid, don't misunderstand me, because these are really very competitive things. You are right, some markets are much more skewed to push and others much more to pull. Obviously, the United States is entirely skewed to pull. If you don't have a pull, I mean the push is only the margin you give to the distributor, that's a given. All the rest is about pull. If you go to Mexico, obviously it's much more the push when you have 260,000 distribution points that you weekly reach. The power of your push is of course much bigger and you can leverage that in another way, that's absolutely true.

But tangentially what we're trying to bring across here that also in Mexico it's not because you go with your lorry to every single point of sale in Mexico that you're going to sell and create excitement for your brands. In Mexico in our operation of CM we clearly have to leverage the pull, it's not good enough. And this is where much more attention goes than in the past in an operation like CM in Mexico. It's in the mix.

And as a follow-on from that. If we look at the development, the business that you bought from FEMSA, you've obviously extracted costs, improved profitability very well and we have another six months of specific savings to come out. Do you think there's enough within ongoing savings to keep growing that margin? Or are we in a period now perhaps of greater investment for those assets to grow that brand pull?
As I said, we have invested more in marketing sales in Mexico to bring the brands to a higher level and that is not something you do six months and that is...
... a sustained effort.
Yeah, absolutely

And we started this year, so indeed in 2010 we were much more geared into the cost thing and taking stock and reorganize and what have you. In 2011, we really started to invest in the brand, that's going to be a long haul program. We'll make that equation work for us.

And one follow-up question. On your fifth pillar, which is about leadership and people, has there anything changed that you can tell us about executive remuneration, that 625 people, are they going to become bigger equity owners in the business? Is their targets becoming longer reaching, I'm trying to get a feel whether you've had some real tangible changes in the remuneration?

All these 635 or 53 people are on that long-term and short-term incentive programs. Those have been designed years ago. The long-term program is paid in stock of the company that we purchase in the market, obviously. And there was our three years rolling programs, which give an attention to the top line growth and the cost in that balance, but perhaps a bit more skewed lately to the revenue growth, so we're very consistent in that.

We have also been introduced, that's more recent, more a forced calibration, because if you want to have an excellent company, you have to a little bit mandate a calibration of your talent. I think it has something competitive, it's a little bit challenging. But I think it bring in good results. We have the first year where we did that. And then, we did touch very clearly business objectives from personal development objectives, so we give attention to both of that.

On the one hand, you got rewards on what you deliver, on the other hand there are skills that you need to develop. And that's skills but also personality traits that you have to work on to make you a better, more performing person. And we devote attention to both of that. And that latter one is also something which is new and we do that consistently across the 600 people in the 71 operations around the world, which you saw here on the chart here.
Thank you.

Sure. Okay. Yeah, Matthew Webb from JPMorgan. Two questions please. First on the CapEx, obviously it's a big step up plan for 2012. I just wondered which markets are going to be the recipients of the additional productive capacity. Obviously, Vietnam has already been mentioned as one. And also whether this is the new normal level of CapEx or whether 2012 is an unusually high year? And also just finally on the CapEx whether there's much in there for TCM2 in the CapEx to get the benefits from that?

And then the second question on input costs, you said that malted barley is the main driver of that. I just wonder whether you'd be willing to disclose roughly the rate of inflation you are expecting on malting barley and also whether that is predominately a European issue or whether it's wider than that? Thanks.

And maybe on the CapEx, the increase is absolutely geared towards developing markets, not Vietnam, because it is not consolidated. So that is not in the free operating cash flow. Therefore it is Africa and it is Latin America. And in Africa, it shouldn't extend its capacity extension, but it is also, for instance, in Nigeria we just bought five breweries with capacity. So there we don't extend capacity. We need to upgrade some of the capacity, but there the investments will be on returnable packaging, because with the growth of the market and the growth of our business, you need bottles and crates and that is under CapEx as well.

When you look at Mexico, there we have a number of big packaging projects and the Carta Blanca brand mentioned by Jean-François, which we fully relaunched in new packaging. Obviously that takes a lot of CapEx. The split between capacity extension and packaging in the extension of the CapEx is around three quarters, one quarter 70-30, three quarters to one quarter. And longer term, I hope that we need as much CapEx as we spend now because that's good news for the business.
Yeah, yeah.

And on your question on the input cost, I don't think we give the split between raw and pack. So we leave it at the 6%, which is a complexion obviously that the raw material has been much more than the pack as you can imagine. And it's true that the barley market is tied to the general grain market, be it that people or farmers grow malting barley for brewing. So the only alternative use is to give it as pick as animal feed, as I always say.

The problem is when the whole crop market is going up, the prices are going up. But there is a lot of individual contracting, because we require from specific varieties that we put on the field. So it not a kind of an open market, but the price is a derivative of that open market. So, there is not a lot of room to maneuver except from long-term contracting and smart spot buying. That is, therefore we don't kind of publish more in detail what the results of that is.
But broadly by geography, the pressure on barley price is higher in Europe and Western Europe?

They were, because that is of course related to the, and brewing barley, the big market, it's North America and Europe. The rest is much more and you have a bit in Australia too. But we derive the bulk of our purchases come from malt come from Europe. Africa is supplied from Europe, Europe is supplied from Europe. Obviously, the Americas are supplied from Americas. That's a bit how it works and Asia is a mixed bag between Europe and Australia, roughly.
Thanks very much.
We have one from the web.
The web, the web.
Thank you. Your next question comes from Robert Vos from ABN Ambro. Please go ahead.

Yes. Hi, good afternoon. I have a couple of questions. When you said that growth in Russia may be slightly down, were you referring to the market or to your Russian business? And related to that, can we still expect some recovery related to both market growth from Heineken in 2012 in Russia?

Second question, excluding country mix, you mentioned that revenue per hectoliter was up 2.2% in 2011. Is it fair to assume that this will be higher in 2012? And thirdly, can you also say a few words on the regional split of the TCM costs and savings? Thank you.

Russia, no the comment was made on the market, slightly down, certainly not on our business. So, we will continue to go for market share in Russia. The 2.2% price mix with result in geographic thing was in 2011. We will work hard to get a price mix again in 2012. It's too early to give a figure on that, because we are in certain markets still negotiating and seeing what we can do.

Secondly, it is also your build up of your portfolio as we have said, more Desperados more Heineken, and more Zywiec and that will help you in your overall price mix. So, it's not only pricing towards the retailers or the wholesalers, it's also the developments in the markets.

Then for TCM, as with the previous programs, Europe will continue to take the lion share of the program, but with initiatives like the global procurement company obviously that gets more a global skill. That take for the coming years that it will be still very much huge to Europe, the financial shared service center is for the first coming years catering for the European companies, it's the idea to enlarge it afterwards to other geographies. But first, we're all in Europe. Europe will have the biggest part of the program as it has done before.
Okay, thank you.
[Question Inaudible] (01:57:38).
No, we said we will try to mitigate the impact of the input costs by pricing, but we have not said that we will offset that impact.
So, the comment is that you will attempt to mitigate the input cost through pricing?
Yeah thanks.

And then when you answer the question about the phasing of the cost – GBS cost versus the savings, would it be correct to interpret that, that there will a net savings in 2012, a positive net savings number?
Well, let's not decompose TCM, that is, I already regret that we've given you €500 million.
Because there we get the next step.
I told you.
Maybe I can make it simpler and at the moment, the market is forecasting is 5% growth in your EBIT for 2012. Are you comfortable with that number?
This year, we're going to profit forecast let's...
No, no and no.

And then is it possible that you can comment on what you're seeing happening currently in your European market especially, are you seeing any inflection points, inflection in the trading? France has been very strong, Netherlands is your big market. Can you see austerity measures having a greater impact this year? I know that's not the peak consumption period, but any comments would be welcome.

The biggest risk that you face, it's besides the self-inflicted price rises because of the input costs, but it's those who can be in addition inflicted by governments and they can be painful. Those are things that are difficult to mitigate because at the end of the day, it's the sovereign state who decides that. As far as we can see and up so far, we have been able to manage that. And a lot of governments have also made a tradeoff of not killing the goose that lays the golden eggs, if you will. But if you take a specific case like Greece and I would take two examples, one is Greece where you know in the past two, three years they have been causing, doubling the excise duties over a period of 18 months and that has of course, had its effect on demand.

That's bringing the whole equation into a negative spiral. Opposed to that was the reaction of the government of Ireland who lowered the excise duties in an attempt to alleviate not us, but the pub industry, because you have a lot of independent pub owners. And that worked very well for them and for us as an industry. So, you have both extremes in front of stressed situations. But I would guess that these are the kind of risk that we face. You cannot build them in. You know what can happen, but that is what it is. I guess if I would look at the whole of Europe, it's obvious that a country like Greece is in a very bad state and that will remain so for quite a bit of time. Volumes are down, were down 12% last year.

We still have a profitable operation with good margins. We command a high market share, which is kind of a saving therein. But on the other hand, Greece is not representing, we are very much diversified. So, this is bearable for a group like Heineken. It's very difficult for me to make what could happen this on the other country, but we all feel that Europe is in a recession. And it's not going to be a pretty place, but that is not a reason to step away from the programs that we have engaged on, which are long-term programs aimed at two things, continue to improve our cost base in Europe.

We are busy with that since 10 years in a row. Mind you, we closed 46 plants malting and brewing over the last 10 years here in Europe. So, the productivity and cost-savings measures are really deeply embedded in our European organization and we are convinced that you have to continue to invest in your top line even if the market shrinks, go for share and value share.

And it's that constant re-adaptation of going for share, but re-tailor your base that makes that in the majority of our countries. Despite all the havoc, we are making progress in terms of return. Yes, it's a heavy work, but still Europe is a very large cash flow source for us and has been historically fueling all our expansion overseas, making us able to transform the profile of our group to a European company and towards a much more worldwide company and skewed towards emerging markets, which we hope will bring mechanically with the demographic growth and the economic growth.

And if that continues, we'll bring us in to better territory of over time in a higher growth profile over time. And of course, in those economies you can speak for hours about the interdependence of the growth in the emerging markets and what's happening in the developed world because it's still quite interdependent. But we are part of the larger world and we have to do what it takes to make our position stronger.
If I may just close, would it be possible to update us on your performance of Heineken Amstel and Windhoek Light in South Africa and what the competitive dynamics are in that markets? Thank you.
Look we grew our volumes, I mean normally, we don't disclose volumes in markets, but you know what goes out of the gate of the brewery we can measure right and that grew by four...

4.1% last year. That is Amstel, Heineken and Windhoek. And we have a stellar performance of Windhoek, a very good performance of Heineken, and a somewhat mediocre performance of Amstel. But when I say mediocre it was not growth, it's kind of mid-single digit decrease on the Amstel brand. I want to say that because I know that some numbers are flying around, around that, but those were the results that we acted in 2011.

So, we still see that for our portfolio as a reasonable good year of growth. We kind of grew perhaps a little bit ahead of the market, at least with the market. So, that it is a competitive market, that's for sure. I mean, make no mistake. We know how determined the competitor is, but as we are. But once more, we compete in the premium end of the market and this is really where we want to focus our efforts and attention. And again, it's building the pool, which is that gets the lion's share of our attention.
We'll take one more question.
One last question.

Thank you. (02:05:20) three questions. I understand you don't want to give guidance, no guidance on EBITDA, I understand that, but when I look at the EBIT margin performance in 2011, if I extract Asia, right, and a lot of that clearly like suppose goes to APB, most of your divisions were down in terms of margins. So, would you want to care to give some color in terms of how margins, where could they be up in 2012, in what regions? So that's one question.

The second one, how concerned should we be about Americas being a drag on EBIT margin expansion? The reason I say that is because I estimated margins in the U.S. and Brazil are probably single-digits for you. And I wondered if the Mexican margins given the share loss to Modelo are sustainable.

And then the third and last question regarding OXXO, what color can you give us there and what percentage of the sales of FEMSA Cerveza in Mexico go through OXXO if the FEMSA people once they are out of the shares, could also open up the doors to Modelo. Can you comment on that please? Thank you.

Maybe let me go round to EBIT margin, we explained already the EBIT margin in Africa, the effect of the new acquisitions in Egypt, Western Europe. Margin was up and that was based on cost and price mix. If we look at Central and Eastern Europe, there you see the effect of Greece on your margins and because obviously in that region, Greece has by far the highest margins. If you look at the Americas, there you see a slight decline, but that is the effect of the first four months of Brazil and Mexico.

Overall, the margins in Mexico are in line with what we have in the Americas, but there is a seasonality and it's so the first four months having relatively low operating margin and these are consolidated in. And as you said Asia had a strong increase in the margins. So that is a bit, the picture.
OXXO?

On OXXO, it's a very important customer for us, we like the corporation and we have an 10 year contract, which still runs for 8.5 years. And what will happen afterwards is unclear. But just to give you a thought, when we did the acquisition, we have been contemplating to say "Why going for exclusivity in the OXXO stores, why not opening it up?" That means that you have to pay less margin because obviously you pay for the exclusivity. There is a benefit for both. And then OXXO could sell more beer, we have to pay less margin. Ultimately, we have chosen for the exclusivity and we are very happy, because it's a good way to build our brands. And that is exactly what Mexico is needing. And in 8.5 years, we are not too worried if that exclusivity would go away if that will go with the proper margin structures accompanying that or linked to it.
And we have 8.5 years to make this brand stronger overall and that is where we bank on.
Again, sorry, just to follow-up on the America. So the margins for the U.S. business you are saying are similar to what have in the rest of that region?

Not of the U.S. business, the U.S. business has higher margins is in the imports business. And Mexico is overall not having a big impact on the region as a whole, but the first four months had a bit that downwards had effect on the margins overall, I'm sure you won't to see that next year back.
I think we are done.
So we thank you.
We do it at the beer. Okay.
Can we take a beer?
Let's go for a perfect beer.
Thank you.
Desperados.
All right.
